channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.

item.content:encoded:

item.title: Developmental convergence and divergence in human stem cell models of autism
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10047-5

Risk associated with genetically defined forms of autism spectrum disorder (ASD) can propagate by means of transcriptional regulation to affect convergently dysregulated pathways, providing insight into the convergent impact of ASD genetic risk on human neurodevelopment.
item.dc:title: Developmental convergence and divergence in human stem cell models of autism

item.title: Projected impacts of climate change on malaria in Africa
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10015-z

item.title: Constraints on axion dark matter by distributed intercity quantum sensors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10034-w

Amplification and optimal noise filtering in hyperpolarized noble-gas spins of observations from distributed intercity quantum sensors monitoring for unexpected transient rotations of polarized spins set parameter range constraints in the search for axion dark matter.

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09977-x

The existence of a long-lived, prethermal regime in many-body systems with tunable heating rates, driven by structured random protocols, is observed using a 78-qubit superconducting quantum processor.
item.dc:title: Prethermalization by random multipolar driving on a 78-qubit processor

item.title: Multimodal learning with next-token prediction for large multimodal models
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10041-x

Emu3 enables large-scale text, image and video learning based solely on next-token prediction, matching the generation and perception performance of task-specific methods, with implications for the development of scalable and unified multimodal intelligence systems.
item.dc:title: Multimodal learning with next-token prediction for large multimodal models

item.title: Radiation-tolerant atomic-layer-scale RF system for spaceborne communication
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10027-9

Using a wafer-scale monolayer 2D MoS2 process instead of conventional silicon-based devices to manufacture components of spaceborne communication systems demonstrates radiation tolerance, low bit error rate and long-term stability, even under much harsher radiation environments.
item.dc:title: Radiation-tolerant atomic-layer-scale RF system for spaceborne communication

item.title: Intestinal macrophages modulate synucleinopathy along the gut–brain axis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09984-y

Muscularis macrophages, housekeepers of enteric nervous system integrity and intestinal homeostasis, modulate α-synuclein pathology and neurodegeneration in models of Parkinson’s disease, and understanding the accompanying mechanisms could pave the way for early-stage biomarkers.

item.title: Environmentally driven immune imprinting protects against allergy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10001-5

In a mouse model, environmental immunostimulation in early life led to cross-reactive adaptive immune memory and reduced type II immune responses to allergens, indicating a mechanistic relationship between environmental antigen exposure and subsequent allergy.
item.dc:title: Environmentally driven immune imprinting protects against allergy

item.title: Population-scale sequencing resolves determinants of persistent EBV DNA
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10020-2

Population-scale WGS reveals genetic determinants of persistent EBV DNA, linking immune regulation—especially antigen processing and MHC class II variation—to EBV persistence and heterogeneous disease associations.
item.dc:title: Population-scale sequencing resolves determinants of persistent EBV DNA

item.title: Pesticide residues alter taxonomic and functional biodiversity in soils
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09991-z

A wide survey of pesticide effects on soil biodiversity across 373 sites in Europe reveals that pesticide residues occur in 70% of sites and have major effects on soil biodiversity and functional ecology.
item.dc:title: Pesticide residues alter taxonomic and functional biodiversity in soils

item.title: Bandwidth-tuned Mott transition and superconductivity in moiré WSe<sub>2</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10049-3

Tunable moiré WSe2 bilayers realize Hubbard-model physics, exhibiting antiferromagnetism, strange metals and superconducting domes, offering a controllable platform to study high-transition-temperature superconductivity.

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10037-7

Human genetic loci that associate with composition of the oral microbiome are identified using saliva-derived DNA, where the same host genetics also shapes oral health and genetic variation in oral bacteria.
item.dc:title: Human and bacterial genetic variation shape oral microbiomes and health

item.title: Frequency reproducibility of solid-state thorium-229 nuclear clocks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09999-5

The nuclear clock transition of 229mTh in 229Th:CaF2 crystals is characterized as a function of doping concentration, temperature and time, demonstrating high reproducibility and identifying ideal operating characteristics of these crystals as nuclear clocks.
item.dc:title: Frequency reproducibility of solid-state thorium-229 nuclear clocks

item.title: PAF15–PCNA exhaustion governs the strand-specific control of DNA replication
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10011-3

PCNA–PAF15 has a key role in determining replisome dynamics during genome replication and protecting against genome instability.
item.dc:title: PAF15–PCNA exhaustion governs the strand-specific control of DNA replication

item.title: A Cambrian soft-bodied biota after the first Phanerozoic mass extinction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10030-0

The Huayuan biota exhibits extraordinary biodiversity, illuminating the impact of the Phanerozoic mass extinction around 513 million years ago and offering critical insights into the transformation of global ecosystems in the early Cambrian.
item.dc:title: A Cambrian soft-bodied biota after the first Phanerozoic mass extinction

item.title: An X-ray-emitting protocluster at z ≈ 5.7 reveals rapid structure growth
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09973-1

Discovery of a protocluster at z = 5.68, merely one billion years after the Big Bang, suggests that large-scale structure must have formed more rapidly in some regions of the early universe than previously thought.

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09959-z

An integrated optical parametric amplifier on thin-film lithium niobate achieves more than 17 dB gain with less than 200 mW input power.

item.title: A prophage-encoded abortive infection protein preserves host and prophage spread
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10070-6

A Gifsy-1 prophage–encoded higher eukaryotes and prokaryotes nucleotide-binding protein, HepS, senses Siphoviridae infection, activates abortive defence by cleaving host transfer RNAs, blocks rival phages and avoids self-targeting via tail-tip variation.

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10023-z

The cytoplasm can be partitioned into distinct compartments by microtubule structures, which can be stabilized by distinct mechanisms in different species.
item.dc:title: Robust cytoplasmic partitioning by solving a cytoskeletal instability

item.title: Advancing regulatory variant effect prediction with AlphaGenome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10014-0

AlphaGenome, a deep learning model that inputs 1-Mb DNA sequence to predict functional genomic tracks at single-base resolution across diverse modalities, outperforms existing models in variant effect prediction and enables comprehensive genomic analysis.

item.title: A cavity-array microscope for parallel single-atom interfacing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10035-9

A cavity-array microscope is realized using intra-cavity lenses to create a two-dimensional array of over 40 modes, each coupled to a single atom in free-space.

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10054-6

A large cross-population atlas of gene–environment interactions reveals how age, sex and lifestyle shape genetic effects, heritability, prediction accuracy and disease biology, with implications for personalized medicine and drug development.

item.title: Psychedelics elicit their effects by 5-HT<sub>2A</sub> receptor-mediated G<sub>i</sub> signalling
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10061-7

Psychedelics and their non-hallucinogenic analogues were compared, revealing that serotonin 2A receptor (5-HT2AR)-mediated Gi signalling is essential for hallucinogenic effect, with the functional mechanisms underlying this providing insights for designing therapeutic drugs without hallucinogenic effects.
item.dc:title: Psychedelics elicit their effects by 5-HT<sub>2A</sub> receptor-mediated G<sub>i</sub> signalling

item.title: Limit of atomic-resolution-tomography reconstruction of amorphous nanoparticles
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09924-w

A simulation approach is used to ascertain the limitations on the structural and chemical information that atomic-resolution electron tomography can determine from noisy electron images.
item.dc:title: Limit of atomic-resolution-tomography reconstruction of amorphous nanoparticles
item.dc:creator: Robert Busch
Peter Rez
Michael M. J. Treacy
Jian-Min Zuo

item.title: Optofluidic three-dimensional microfabrication and nanofabrication
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10033-x

A strategy compatible with a broad range of materials by precisely manipulating optofluidic interactions within a confined 3D space to control the assembly of colloidal microparticles/nanoparticles is demonstrated, enabling the precise manufacture of complex microstructures/nanostructures.
item.dc:title: Optofluidic three-dimensional microfabrication and nanofabrication
item.dc:creator: Xianglong Lyu
Wenhai Lei
Gaurav Gardi
Muhammad Turab Ali Khan
Shervin Bagheri
Mingchao Zhang
Metin Sitti

item.title: Ferromagnet-like binary switching of a Stoner–Wohlfarth antiferromagnet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10019-9

CrPS4, a 2D van der Waals A-type antiferromagnet, is shown to exhibit ideal characteristics of Stoner–Wohlfarth antiferromagnets, such as ferromagnet-like binary switching rather than layer-by-layer flipping as in other 2D A-type antiferromagnets.
item.dc:title: Ferromagnet-like binary switching of a Stoner–Wohlfarth antiferromagnet

item.title: The Ocean Equity Index
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09976-y

The Ocean Equity Index provides a systematic, twelve-criteria framework to assess and improve equity in ocean initiatives, projects and policies, producing structured data that guide evidence-based decisions and support more equitable outcomes for coastal communities and ecosystems.
item.dc:title: The Ocean Equity Index

item.title: A flexible digital compute-in-memory chip for edge intelligence
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09931-x

A flexible digital artificial intelligence chip with a compute-in-memory architecture is fabricated using a commercial low-temperature polycrystalline silicon thin-film transistor process and shows high accuracy in human daily activity monitoring using multimodal physiological signals.
item.dc:title: A flexible digital compute-in-memory chip for edge intelligence

item.title: Optical control over topological Chern number in moiré materials
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09851-w

Optical spin orientation of itinerant ferromagnets in twisted MoTe2 homobilayers is demonstrated, enabling control of topological Chern numbers with circularly polarized light.
item.dc:title: Optical control over topological Chern number in moiré materials

item.title: Disentangling multiple gas kinematic drivers in the Perseus galaxy cluster
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10017-x

Kinematic measurements of the Perseus galaxy cluster reveal two drivers of gas motions: a small-scale driver in the inner core associated with black-hole feedback and a large-scale driver in the outer core powered by mergers.
item.dc:title: Disentangling multiple gas kinematic drivers in the Perseus galaxy cluster

item.title: Holistic motor control of zebra finch song syllable sequences
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10069-z

A cortical premotor network in HVC, once initiated, can sustain and regulate the sequential production of zebra finch song syllables without major extrinsic inputs.
item.dc:title: Holistic motor control of zebra finch song syllable sequences

item.title: A benchmark of expert-level academic questions to assess AI capabilities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09962-4

Humanity’s Last Exam, a multi-modal benchmark at the frontier of human knowledge, is designed to be an expert-level closed-ended academic benchmark with broad subject coverage.
item.dc:title: A benchmark of expert-level academic questions to assess AI capabilities

item.title: GlycoRNA complexed with heparan sulfate regulates VEGF-A signalling
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10052-8

Heparan sulfate proteoglycans facilitate the assembly of clusters of glycoRNAs and cell surface RNA-binding proteins, which negatively modulate VEGF-A signalling and angiogenesis.
item.dc:title: GlycoRNA complexed with heparan sulfate regulates VEGF-A signalling

item.title: Pre-assembly of biomolecular condensate seeds drives RSV replication
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10071-5

Viral ribonucleoprotein–viral protein networks form pre-replication centres that nucleate viral factories and drive respiratory syncytial virus replication.

item.title: Structures of Ostα/β reveal a unique fold and bile acid transport mechanism
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10029-7

Cryogenic electron microscopy structures of human Ostα/β uncover a unique transport pathway featuring two substrate-binding sites connected by an amphipathic helix-gated conduit, and electrophysiological studies demonstrate voltage-sensitive, bidirectional transport, showing its efflux role in vivo.
item.dc:title: Structures of Ostα/β reveal a unique fold and bile acid transport mechanism

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09986-w

Transition of superfluid to insulator is observed in the layer-imbalanced regime of bilayer magnetoexcitons.
item.dc:title: Observation of a superfluid-to-insulator transition of bilayer excitons

item.title: Optical switching of a moiré Chern ferromagnet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10048-4

Optical switching of a moiré Chern ferromagnet is demonstrated in twisted molybdenum ditelluride bilayers using continuous-wave circularly polarized light, paving the way for dissipationless spintronics and quantized Chern junction devices.
item.dc:title: Optical switching of a moiré Chern ferromagnet

item.title: Vagal blood volume receptors compensate for haemorrhage and posture change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10010-4

A vagal reflex to blood volume changes in the heart involves PIEZO2 and helps to stabilize blood pressure in an upright posture and after blood loss.

item.title: Structure and mechanism of the human bile acid transporter OSTα–OSTβ
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09934-8

Cryo-electron microscopy structures of the bile acid transporter OSTα–OSTβ, which has a key role in bile acid homeostasis, provide insight into its distinct architecture and mechanism of substrate translocation.

item.title: Act now to clean up air
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00108-8

New regulations are needed to deal with increasing environmental threats to lung health.
item.dc:title: Act now to clean up air
item.dc:creator: Lidia Morawska

item.title: Chill out: freezing temperatures produced by letting a stressed alloy relax
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00030-z

A device has been built that relies on a solid-state phenomenon called the elastocaloric effect to produce cooling to temperatures below 0 °C, lower than existing room-temperature elastocaloric cooling systems are able to achieve. The innovation demonstrates that elastocaloric technology could offer an alternative to conventional freezing systems that use volatile greenhouse gases.
item.dc:title: Chill out: freezing temperatures produced by letting a stressed alloy relax

item.title: Deep-sea robots will search for source of mysterious ‘dark oxygen’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00266-9

Scientists have launched a fresh effort to find out what could be producing oxygen at the bottom of the Pacific Ocean.
item.dc:title: Deep-sea robots will search for source of mysterious ‘dark oxygen’
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Exposome studies can improve lung health
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00106-w

A new set of analytical tools will help researchers to understand the lifelong effects of air pollution.
item.dc:title: Exposome studies can improve lung health
item.dc:creator: Kari C. Nadeau

item.title: AI chatbots are infiltrating social-science surveys — and getting better at avoiding detection
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00221-8

A researcher has created a chatbot that is indistinguishable from human participants in online surveys. Some researchers fear that a workhorse of social science is now under threat.
item.dc:title: AI chatbots are infiltrating social-science surveys — and getting better at avoiding detection
item.dc:creator: Sara Phillips

item.title: A step towards building miniature human livers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04012-5

Recapitulating the complexity of human organs in vitro would accelerate drug discovery and enable personalized treatments. By combining different types of liver cell from donor tissues, in vitro models of a liver region that mirror some of the organ’s main structures and functions can be assembled, getting closer to reproducing mini livers in vitro.
item.dc:title: A step towards building miniature human livers

item.title: Scraps of viral DNA in biobank samples reveal secrets of Epstein–Barr virus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00038-5

Viral DNA that is usually dismissed when sequencing the human genome could help to uncover useful information about complex diseases.
item.dc:title: Scraps of viral DNA in biobank samples reveal secrets of Epstein–Barr virus
item.dc:creator: Kristen J. Wade
Jill A. Hollenbach

item.title: Alternative explanation for how celestial objects generate large-scale magnetic fields
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00026-9

Numerical simulations provide a mechanism that explains how celestial objects such as stars and galaxies can generate ordered, macroscopic magnetic fields. The mechanism arises from turbulence — chaotic changes in the pressure and velocity of fluid — and avoids a physical effect that hinders other proposed systems from explaining observed ordered fields.
item.dc:title: Alternative explanation for how celestial objects generate large-scale magnetic fields

item.title: Funding cuts could put research into emerging threats to lung health at risk
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00104-y

Wildfire smoke, spore-spread fungal diseases and microplastic are all on the rise, even as the US government slashes support for respiratory research and policy.
item.dc:title: Funding cuts could put research into emerging threats to lung health at risk
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer

item.title: Treatments for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis are on the horizon
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00109-7

The life-threatening disease affects millions of people, but has no effective therapy. Drugs under development could target the condition before fibrosis becomes established.
item.dc:title: Treatments for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis are on the horizon
item.dc:creator: Tim Vernimmen

item.title: Six highlights from lung-health research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00111-z

Fibrosis survival, long COVID’s lasting toll and other highlights from lung studies.
item.dc:title: Six highlights from lung-health research
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer

item.title: Expert-level test is a head-scratcher for AI
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04098-x

Conventional benchmarks are becoming less effective at assessing AI performance, but a multi-disciplinary test has set AI systems a fresh challenge.
item.dc:title: Expert-level test is a head-scratcher for AI

item.title: Wikipedia is needed now more than ever, 25 years on
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00074-1

The online encyclopedia is an antidote to an increasingly poisoned information ecosystem. Researchers should help to nourish it.
item.dc:title: Wikipedia is needed now more than ever, 25 years on

item.title: The surprisingly big health benefits of just a little exercise
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00237-0

‘Exercise snacks’ and other forms of everyday movement can greatly reduce the risk of heart disease and death.
item.dc:title: The surprisingly big health benefits of just a little exercise
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Pesticide cocktails negatively affect soil biodiversity
item.content:encoded:

item.dc:title: Pesticide cocktails negatively affect soil biodiversity
item.dc:creator: Brajesh K. Singh

item.title: Could the regenerative power of the lungs help to reverse disease?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00107-9

The ability of the lungs to rebuild themselves has long been underappreciated, now researchers are raising the possibility that it could help to tackle chronic disease.
item.dc:title: Could the regenerative power of the lungs help to reverse disease?
item.dc:creator: Claire Ainsworth

item.title: How ‘forest bathing’ keeps lungs healthy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00105-x

Wooded environments release organic compounds that seem to improve respiratory health, but the magnitude and mechanism of the effect remains unclear.

item.title: A bendable AI chip for wearable technology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00037-6

Co-optimized design and technology has resulted in cheap, flexible microchips that efficiently run neural-network tasks, as demonstrated in wearable health-care devices.
